name: 2-cyanophenol
source: Aldrich Chemical Company; Aldrich Catalog-Handbook of Fine Chemicals; Milwaukee; WI; 1984.

name: 2-cyanophenol
source: Aldrich Chemical Company; Aldrich Catalog-Handbook of Fine Chemicals; Milwaukee; WI; 1984.
Reason: For 2-cyanophenol, we must consider the effects of both the hydroxyl (-OH) group and the nitrile (–C≡N) group on the base structure of benzene. The benzene ring has a basic melting point reference, which we will take as around 5.5 °C for the sake of comparison. The hydroxyl group is known to increase the melting point due to its ability to form hydrogen bonds; this could be estimated as an increase of approximately +70 °C. On the other hand, the nitrile group, being polar and having a cyano group attached directly to the ring, tends to increase the rigidity of the molecule and might contribute an additional +20 °C due to dipole-dipole interactions and potential for cyano group stacking. The sum of contributions from each functional group and the base benzene structure will give us the predicted melting point.
